text: to me it just reads you win the game
I know Henry and I disagree here, but I don't mind "win the game" effects. It just lets everyone shuffle up and go again instead of letting one game drag out longer than it needs to
Plus it creates a sense of urgency, people need to cast their stuff instead of waiting because they're worried because the blue player has mana open

Yea. The way I see it, its just another combo piece usually. It's no different than if someone played a kikki and zelous conscripts. The game ends and you move on. The only difference is that the word draw is used instead of a definitive winner.
“We’re all winners! Right?”
i think a draw means your all losers technically
Just got it off on modo like 5 minutes ago, and the usual rants start up "Why would you even play that card!", "If you didn't want to win why even play"
Yea, you didn't "win," don't try to rain on that parade
If you're not first you're last!
That phrasing also gets around [[!Platinum Angel]] effects since, technically, you don't lose the game.

I realized I never told folks here what happened between us & tappedout. sorry for the delay.

Here is the summary: tappedout became aware of our integration with deckstats (how they have edhrec stats integrated into their website), scryfall (the search), and how I’ve given data dumps to authors to do their self service analysis. I told them about it in passing in another unrelated conversation.

I’d always assumed they’d be chill about this, but apparently they were not. Something along the lines of “that’s our data and you are helping our competitors”. I actually offered to pay them $500/month for their data if i had rights to do whatever i wanted with it, but he still wanted control over the data. He told me to stop my integration with deckstats and scryfall.

At this point, I had no leverage over the situation so I decided to implement Deckstats and mtggoldfish integrations ASAP (with their permission, which they were glad to give).  Those are flowing now.

Eventually TO decided they wouldn’t budge on the control aspect and told me to stop collecting data

I decided to be silent about it and answer questions directly if people ask, but avoid an official announcement. I don’t want to throw tappedout under the bus and if users like using them that’s cool.
They sound kind of like dicks.
It's not even their data necessarily. I have the same decklist up on multiple sites.
seems kind of desperate and insecure to me
but i like to give them the benefit of the doubt and wonder what situation they are in
which is why i didn’t go all crazy and throw them under the bus on social media
It would be the little bus, mind you...
Even if the decklist is up on just their site it's not their date once you make it public facing
But I get not wanting to get into that fight
indeed. the recent linkedin ruling made that clear
however, they are still allowed to ban my ip and i’m not going to fight that fight

At the beginning of each player's upkeep, that player may choose any number of tapped blue creatures he or she controls and pay {4} for each creature chosen this way. If the player does, untap those creatures.

text: Henry soon to be guesting on the command zone podcast
Not at all...I've used it to great effect.
It's a great card. I was just joking that they espouse the virtues of orrery quite a lot
That and infinite mana and how good it makes cards.
It's a good card, but I think Jimmy is a little overboard about it
It's really easy to be non-impactful
If it was non-impactful, then your deck was going to be non-impactful anyhow.
I'm happy with it in my Glissa deck becuase surprise deathtouch is decent
If blue is an option I'd rather (and do) just run leyline
Which is why I said in non-blue decks :wink:
4 mana is a lot for a card that only really works if you have other cards in hand
That benefit
To be clear, it's good. It's just not "OMG EVERY DECK!" like Jimmy seems to claim
No...but I also think folks underestimate how much being able to play at instant speed changes non-blue decks.
They expect it out of blue...
Instant speed Demonic Tutor for any answer is okay I guess :slightly_smiling_face:
Honestly, being able to use sorceries at instant speed to respond to removal or other threats is pretty sweet.
I use it in Gonti to great effect since I often steal crazy sorceries or creatures.
Assuming you're running many sorceries. Gonti makes sense because for the specific thing you're doing you have no choice but to run sorcery speed stuff
It also makes what I steal more impactful.
I remember too many times where I'd draw it, look at my hand and see nothing that really changed the game at instant speed, then being annoyed it was in my hand.
That obviously wasn't always the case. There were times I'd draw it and be happy to see it, but the times I'd draw it and be annoyed were frequent enough to notice
Your commander gets flash if nothing else.
Yeah, but that's not enough of a salve, partiucarly if your commander is out
That's the thing...it may not add immediate value but it adds enormous value over the game.
It provides options you wouldn't normally have as the game progresses.
I'm not arguing against it. If it does work for you, great. I can see that. I've just had enough situations where it didn't.
Sure
I've also come to realize I value consistency
Perhaps too much :wink:
Maybe. All things in moderation, including moderation
I just moved my orrery to meren, so I can cast the things after I get them back. Truly, I live in magical Christmasland
isn't your Meren deck rats?

I've always wondered when the best time to cast orrey is. Too soon and you essentially take a turn off for nothing, too late and you might not have enough cards to make it worth it. Plus, I've had it eat so much wayward removal it's not funny.
Better Orrey than, say, Paradox Engine next turn :wink:
PE is not a card you play on curve. You need to be ready to win when you play it.
I never assume you're going to drop specific cards on curve. But I get your point
But if you have the Orrery out you get to respond to anything (except Krosan Grip) and still win when they go to take out your PE :wink:
I might be in the minority when I say that I don't use PE to straight up win the game
Who lets you leave it on the table for multiple turns?
People without answers in hand.
Silly people...
They're magicing wrong
Which isn't super common. But I've had it happen. I've lived the dream
It's pretty much how Momir wins for me. That or [[Seedborn Muse]]

text: There is a rampant problem with people in my play group never knowing when and where to use removal, if at all. It's even been given its own nickname.
Which is?
(Nice hook :wink:)
<@U340CHVJA> it is!
CATA : completely arbitrary threat assessment. A player can become CATAtonic and a game can become CATAstrophic.

The one that always gets me is when someone plays a slightly larger but non-game winning threat with another one in play. It happened this week where someone played a Mirari's Wake which multple people commented on how it had to go before his next untap. I had a Beast Within all ready if nobody else dealt with it, then the guy the turn before drops a True Conviction forcing me to deal with that.
I'm not sure not playing a threat because another huge one exists is really a smart play or anything
But it still drives me nuts when the one big problem I have to kill turns into a choice between two big problems
Unless it's a slightly less problematic threat...
But that requires a meta that can do appropriate threat assessment.
Or when you have to play janitor for the game, cleaning up everything while other players don't have anything to deal with game ending stufg
Playing around counters is a thing, so I'd think people would wait to see if there's a removeal spell the same way, but they generally don't
I've had to discipline myself not to do that in certain pods with people I know don't run answers
Or I spend the whole game burning resources while everyoen else just does their thing
when I visit in two weeks you're gonna have to tell me who I should meta game against then
I'll let you know :slightly_smiling_face:
Kill <@U4V5EHQ2G> first
Usually a legit strategy
When in doubt, kill anyone named Henry :stuck_out_tongue:

I won't say this irks me, exactly, but it is an area I see many players need to improve upon--frequently other players will remove big bads even when those things aren't threatening them at all. They'll path a blightsteel that was aimed elsewhere. Why not just save your removal for when it actually comes your way? It's dealing damage to opponents, that's what you want
Depends on if you think you can beat the owner of the BBEG
If you think the targeted player is dead and you're shortly afterward, you might help out the enemy of your enemy

That can be a piece of it. I'm a group hug player (and a damn good one) and I know pretty well how to evaluate who I need to keep alive to assist me. Most often I just see knee-jerk reactions, and those I think could use some improvement

Oh, yeah, my example isn't necessarily an "every time" type thing. I know I've "helped" someone with no real gain to myself, but it kept someone in the game so I wasn't the sole target of the strongest player.

I've also had answers to save people and let it go instead, thinking I'd do fine on my own :wink:
Those are honestly my favorite moments when playing group hug. I have three different ways to save player X from player Y, but I don't need player X anymore, so... bye felicia
/gif bye felicia

attachments.fallback: 220x97px image
attachments.text: <http://riffsy.com/view/riff/4614549/|bye felicia>

text: Yeah, okay
Evil as it sounds, that's my favorite part about playing group hug. Kynaios and Tiro are nonblack but in the game I feel like I'm Littlefinger (pre-season-7-Littlefinger, at least)
That's why you always kill the hug player first
Honestly I always think of 'hug' decks as a subtype of Political decks.
Really, there's no such thing as group hug; there's just people who claim they are but they're really just making bad decks and players better
And since I always assume that's everyone who isn't me, kill the hug player first
:stuck_out_tongue:
As I said...kill <@U4V5EHQ2G> first and ignore those lovely henry players. They're the pip.
I'm not entirely joking though; hugs decks tend to speed up the combo player, or reward narrow deck building, neither of which do me any good

Yeah, we've had the discussion before. Your approach makes sense to me. I don't think other players are bad for letting a hug player live, though; I have several combo-tastic folks in my playgroups, and my hug deck is often the only one that can keep them in check, because it has lots of hugs but also tons of removal. When you sit down with a K&T, Breya combo, and a Rafiq kill-you-quickly, it can be tough to justify always killing the hug player. They give your opponents cards, but they also aren't immediately punching you in the face. Everyone in my groups knows my reputation with hugs by now but I still get away with the strategy because there are often worse problems on the horizon and I'm one of the few that can keep it in line.
We can all agree on kill Azami first
We definitely agree that hugs are dangerous
I don't like to be touched...

attachments.fallback: 220x95px image
